title: Two pipes can fill a tank in 10 hours and 12 hours respectively, while a third pipe empties the full tank m 20 hours. If all the three pipes operate simultaneously, in how much time will the tank be full? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let two filling pipes be A and B, draining pipe is C. Given that pipe A can fill a tank in 10 hours => In one hour it fills 1/10th part of the tank ( by cross multiplication method) And pipe B can fill a tank in 12 hours => In one hour it fills 1/12th part of the tank. And also given pipe C empties the tank in 20 hours => in one hour it empties 1/20th part. If all three pipes operate simultaneously work done by both pipes A and B in one hour will be added and C work is subtracted. Therefore work done by three pipes in one hour = 1/10 + 1/12 -1/20 = 8/60 In 1 hour 8/60th part of a tank can be filled. Then complete tank can be filled in 60/8 = 7.5hrs ( by cross multiplication)

Consider x, y and z are the velocity in three different pipes and v as volume of he tank. Then, 10x = 12y = 20z = v Hence y = x/2 x and z = 5x/6 Considering all the three pipes are working, No of hours * (x+y-z) = v No of hours *(x + 1/2x + 5/6x) = v No of hours*4x/3 = v With velocity of x, the tank is filled in 10 hrs. Then with velocity of 4x/3, time taken will be 3*10/4 = 7.5 hrs When all the three pipes are working simultaneously, time taken to fill the tank is 7.5 hours

Let Pipe A fill the tank in 10 hours. So A fills (1/10)th of the tank in 1 hour. Let Pipe B fill the tank in 12 hours. So B fills (1/12)th of the tank in 1 hour. Let Pipe C empty the tank in 20 hours. So C empties (1/20)th of the tank in 1 hour. If all the three pipes are open together they fill (1/10)+(1/12)-(1/20) = (6/60)+(5/60)-(3/60) = 8/60 = (1/7.5)th in 1 hour. The tank will get filled in 7.5 hours.

Let the TWO filling pipes be ‘A' and ‘B'. The draining pipe be ‘C'In 1- hour pipe A can fill= 1/10 the tank .1- hour pipe B can fill = 1/12 the tank.In 1- hour pipe C can drain = 1/20 the tank.If all the pipes operate, in 1- hour the part of the tank filled =1/10+1/12-1/20= (6+5–3)/60= 8/60= 2/15.So to fill the full-time tank, when all the pipes operate= 1/(2/15)= 15/2= 7.5 Hours.Or it will take 7-hours and 30- minutes

Algebric method: Let the capacity of the tank = x litres 1st pipe fills in 1 hr = x/10 litres 2nd pipe fills in 1 ht = x/12 litres 3rd pipe empties in 1 hr = x/20 litres In 1 hr the tank fills with = x/10 + x/12-x/20 = 6x+5x-3x / 60 = 8x/60 = 2x/15 litres Time taken to fill the full tank(x litres) = x ÷ 2x/15 = 15/2 = 7.5 litres = 7hr 30 min

In 1 hour pipe A will fill 1/10th of the tank. In 1 hour pipe B will fill 1/12th of the tank. In 1 hour pipe C will empty 1/20th of the tank. So in 1 hour, total 1/10+ 1/12 - 1/20 = 8/60 part is full in 1 hour. So in 60/8 hours , the tank will be full. 60/8 = 7.5 hours

Pipe A is filling the tank 1/10 (6/60)rate per hour Pipe B is filling the tank 1/12 ( 5/60)rate per hour Pipes A & B combined are both filling the tank at a rate of 11/60 per hour. Pipe C is emptying the tank at a rate of 1/20 or 3/60 per hour. Recalculated filling rates are now 8/60 per hour. 60 divided by 8 = Answer: The water tank will be 100% full in 7.5 hours
In an hour Tank filled by Pipe A= 1/10 Tank filled by Pipe B= 1/12 Tank empty pipe C=1/20 Combined 1/10+1/12–1/20 = 2/15 of the tank filled in an hour Time for full tank = 15/2*1= 7.5 hours
X/10 + X/12 - X/20 = 1 (one because it does one work) 12x + 10× - 6x = 120 16x = 120 X=7.5 hours = 7hour and 30min
In one hour filled tank=1/10+1/12–1/20=(6+5–3)/60=7/60 tank. Therefore total time to fill tank=60/7 hours= 8 hours and 34.3 min.
In 1 hour they will fill 1/10 +1/12 - 1/20= (6+5 -3) /60= 8/60=2/15 So tank is filled in 15/2 = 7.5 hours ANSWER
